I have some questions, a couple of suggestions.

Why is `address.js` this kind of pseudo-private module that shouldnt be
directly imported by clients? It could just expose:

```js
declare module "address" {
  declare opaque type NodeAddress;
  declare opaque type EdgeAddress;
  declare function nodeAddress(parts: $ReadOnlyArray<string>): NodeAddress;
  declare function edgeAddress(parts: $ReadOnlyArray<string>): EdgeAddress;
  declare function toParts(address: NodeAddress | EdgeAddress): string[];
}
```

If you want the assertion functions to be visible for test code only,
or test code and `graph.js`, you can just underscore-name them. (Though
I dont see a problem with the assertions being part of the public
APIIm happy to include them or exclude them, as you prefer.)

Whats with all the underscore-names in `address.js`? (Are you trying to
get around cannot declare `NodeAddress` because the name is already
bound or something? If so, just `export`-`from`, or `import` with an
alias.)

Why export an object `_Address` containing functions? This is unsafe
(callers may freely and typesafely modify the attributes on the object)
and annoying (callers can no longer import individual values). If you
export values individually, callers can either import them individually
or `import * as Address from "./address"` (which _is_ safe).

If you want to re-export the members of `address.js` from `graph.js`,
thats probably fine with me (depending on how you do it).

It seems desirable that `NodeAddress` and `EdgeAddress` should be
[declared as opaque subtypes][1] of `string`:

```js
export opaque type NodeAddress: string = string;
export opaque type EdgeAddress: string = string;
```

This enables other modules to safely reason about reference semantics
(i.e., that `(===)` coincides with logical equality), and therefore use
these in `Set`s and `Map`s, dont have to worry about defensively
copying them, etc. Clients still wont be able to obtain them from
strings: if `a1` and `a2` are addresses, then `a1 + a2` is _not_ an
address (which is good).

[1]: https://flow.org/en/docs/types/opaque-types/#toc-subtyping-constraints

Im not dead-set against using union types in public APIs for things
like `toParts` and `concat`. However, I thoroughly disagree that this is
simplerone function that has a bounded wildcard with an upper bound
of a union type is clearly more complicated than two monomorphic
functions with simple domain and codomain. Is there an advantage here
besides implementation laziness (no offense)? That is, under what
circumstances is there a value whose type is known to be either
`NodeAddress` or `EdgeAddress`, but were not sure which one? This
cant be a very useful type for callers, because it is incompatible with
every method on `Graph` (you cant `addNode` or `hasEdge` or anything,
and with good reason). Im feeling very when in doubt, leave it out.

Why allow `nodeAddress` and `edgeAddress` to be called with `undefined`?
This seems like a great way to mask bugs: if a client passes `undefined`
instead of an array, it seems at least as likely that the client has a
bug causing their intended-array to be `undefined` than that they
actually want the address given by `[]`. If a client does want this
semantics, they can just write `myArrayOrUndefined || []`.

The following two tests would have passed in the previous API, but fail
under the code in this pull request:

```js
describe("toParts", () => {
  it("throws on fake (slash-separated) node address", () => {
    // $ExpectFlowError
    expect(() => toParts("N/bad/stuff\0")).toThrow();
  });
  it("throws on fake (slash-separated) edge address", () => {
    // $ExpectFlowError
    expect(() => toParts("E/bad/stuff\0")).toThrow();
  });
});
```

Is this intentional? If so, why?

Note that `typeof NODE | typeof EDGE` is just `Symbol`; there is no
additional safety granted by using that definition.

I like the tests that node and edge addresses are distinct at both the
type layer and the value layer.

Ooh, another benefit to using : Everywhere that I was writing "Cred", I can now write "red". That makes it extremely transparent that  stands for red. I made a PR that effects this switch in the README (#3) take a look maybe?

Another benefit to  (or any other symbol that visually looks like a C): if someone wants to write 1000 but doesn't know how to grab that unicode symbol, they can just write 1000C and it will still be pretty clear what they mean.

Two notes on the lunate sigma:
  - At least to me, it is very hard to distinguish from a standard "C". The dot is small and not prominent, as opposed to the strokes in the dollar, euro, pound, etc. signs.
  - We would need to specify "dotted lunate sigma", which is not the standard variant. A capital lunate sigma (U+03F9) is just  ``; the dotted one is U+03FE  ``. (Somewhat unfortunatelyif [unsourced Wikipedia][1] is to be believedthe dotted form is "an editorial sign indicating that the line so marked is at an incorrect position.")

[1]: https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sigma&oldid=822738925#Lunate_sigma

My two cents:
  - I like U+A4 CURRENCY SIGN  ``. It's kind of amusing that you suggested it without knowing the currency-related meaning! :-) Interpreting "unknown currency" as "arbitrary currency" seems very appropriate to me. The standard glyph is simple and unambiguous.
  - *And* it's in Latin-1, whichpractically speakinghas the potential to avert a lot of problems. Of the options in Latin-1, it seems the best to me.
  - As a less-valuable-but-also-nice technical boon, the catcode of  is "Symbol, Currency", while  is "Letter, Uppercase".
  - I suspect that picking anything that looks like the "cents" symbol, as in a few of the examples, would lead people to read "GitCents" and "TensorFlowCents", which doesn't really match what you want.

Thanks for the offer @VictorBjelkholm. My instinct right now is to use Travis - it's simpler, I'm more familiar with it, it's free, and I'm almost certain it will solve all our immediate needs. Happy to hear any arguments in favor of using jenkins, though.

> * should be able to read git data, probably via NodeGit

Ive been doing a bunch of hacking with `nodegit` and `simple-git`. Here are my thoughts.

Of the two, `simple-git` (known on GitHub as `steveukx/git-js`) is certainly simpler. It provides a JS veneer over standard Git APIs. But I think that it may be too simple. Most of its commands seem to be wrappers around the actual `git(1)` CLI, whose output is parsed by `simple-git`. But this parsing is flakye.g., `repo.log(['--stat'])` silently gives completely wrong output, and `repo.log(['--follow', filename])` has the same issue that `gitpython` does with renames (creating filenames like `"file => file2"`).

We might have to consider coming back to `simple-git`, but its not my top choice. Combine the fact that it will spawn a ton of subprocesses (not great) with the fact that it doesnt even do a great job of parsing the output, and I dont see a compelling reason to use it.

Now, `nodegit` takes a different approach. It exposes direct bindings to `libgit2`, and in fact is the official set of JS bindings for this standard library (as seen on [the `libgit2` homepage][libgit2]). This suggests to me that it should theoretically have better support. In my opinion, the library has two major downsides. First, while the documentation serves as a useful skeleton for the type hierarchies and structures, its explanatory value is next to nothing. For instance, [heres the page for `Revwalk`][nodegit-revwalk]. I can gather that its supposed to walk over revisions, and I can see what _types_ of arguments Im supposed to pass to the `push*` family of functionsbut I have no idea what they actually do. (Why does a file walker need a stack?) The `hide` options are even more confusing.

That said, the failures of the documentation are partially mitigated by the fact that `nodegit`s architecture very closely mirrors that of `libgit2` itself, and `libgit2`s documentation is far better. The [`libgit2` documentation for `git_revwalk_push`][libgit2-revwalk-push] answers all my questions in plain English. (Believe it or not, it was easier for me to write a working program using `libgit2` in C than the same program using `nodegit` in JS, given that I did the latter first.)

The other problem that I have with `nodegit` is that well, Ive just had an unusual of trouble getting simple examples working. Things like, their docs say that a callback is called with `(null, null)` when iteration finishes, but its actually called with `(someErrorObject, undefined)`. I even managed to get a ten-line program, basically copied from their examples, to throw a `SIGABRT` (134) and hard-crash all of node ([issue details])this worries me a bit.

In summary: I really want to like `nodegit`, but Im not sure that its the right choice, either. Maybe parsing the output of `git(1)` CLI commands really is simpler. Im open to opinions.

[libgit2]: https://libgit2.github.com/
[nodegit-revwalk]: http://www.nodegit.org/api/revwalk/
[libgit2-revwalk-push]: https://libgit2.github.com/libgit2/#HEAD/group/revwalk/git_revwalk_push
[issue details]: https://github.com/nodegit/nodegit/issues/1442

NodeGit seems to be basically unmaintained - observe the two month-old PRs with no comments or progress, and very spare activity on the issues. So, given that you're running into so many issues, I think the only feasible way to use this would be to fork it (with an eventual hope of merging all our improvements back in).

SimpleGit seems to have an active owner and maintenance, but as you note it doesn't look like a perfect match for us. If we were to use it, I think it would be another case where we should fork it, fix it up to our needs, but with a better trajectory for merging it back.

So - given that we will be maintaining a Git API, which is best? Fork nodegit, fork simplegit, or roll our own? Rolling our own makes sense to me - we only need a small subset of Git integration; since we only care about reads and not writes, we will focus our attention differently and get the semantics precisely correct for our use case. However, it seems like there are two major approaches: we can wrap the CLI (in which case we may benefit by taking some code from SimpleGit) or we can wrap libgit2 (in which case we may benefit taking some code from NodeGit).

Alternatively, we could take a step back and re-assess whether we want to use Node for the backend, given that when we made the call for Node, we believed we would have high-quality git libraries. But I still think using Node is worth it; being able to share code, types, testing, and infrastructure across the frontend and backend will make maintaining the system a lot easier. Also, I don't see compelling advantages to using any other language (Go or Python) as the backend.

> So - given that we will be maintaining a Git API, which is best? Fork nodegit, fork simplegit, or roll our own?

I think that before we attempt to answer this question, we should nail down exactly what it is that we want from git: for instance, come up with a formal spec for the functions that were trying to implement, and worry about implementing them later. There are a couple of points in particular that I think we have not fully explored:

 1. After the allocation, which values are going to be persisted as part of a permanent (but evolving) datastore, as opposed to solely being used transiently in the initial construction process?
 2. How will later allocations build incrementally on the work from the original allocation?
 3. What do we do with merge commits (and nonlinear histories in general)?

Perhaps surprisingly, I think that (3) is the most important questionits not just an implementation detail; rather, it informs the answers to the previous two questions, and in fact restricts the sets of possible answers. (Part of this has to do with gits internal object model, and part of it stems from loose interpretations of terms like file.) It may be easiest to discuss this in person.

Once weve answered these questions, lets build a rough, but fully functional, implementation using whatever tools are easiest. This probably means interacting with gits plumbing CLI utilities via Python-ish. After that, I expect that we will be able to make a more informed decision on how to interface with git in production code.

The root content of this issue is outdated, since it describes a backend which consists entirely of serving Git data, but now we are pivoting to a pluggable graph-based backend. However, I think the discussion here is still relevant, for the specific question of how to integrate with Git - which makes me think we should either close this (but reference the contents when we develop a git plugin), or cannibalize this thread into something about making a Git plugin.

@wchargin thoughts?
I'm going to close this issue as obsolete. We can reference back to it if we need context on building Git integration, although as it looks complicated I think we can punt on it for the near term.

:+1:

> For each individual component-specific interaction, we can test the logic via unit tests

Agreed. 

> For end-to-end integration, we can describe a sequence of user inputs and then take a snapshot in the terminal state

Perhaps. This suggests to me that the E2E tests snapshot will change frequently: the test could be invalidated by style/copytext changes even at leaf nodes, changes to default sorting/allocation settings, etc. It would be unfortunate if this led to people (read: future-me) regenerating the snapshots blithely enough that actual regressions are not only unnoticed but promoted to the correct behavior. But Im still willing to try it out!

I _do_ agree that we should have E2E things-still-work tests for each major feature. Such tests are probably easy enough to write without snapshot testingDOM inspection is made pretty easy by helper functions like `findManyWithTag`, `findUniqueWithId`, etc. For instance, the test that you describe with `UserExplorer` displays new sums is easy to write in this way.

Heck, we could write both versions, and see which ones give better ROC curves. :-)

> based on past experience, retro-converting a complicated system designed without plugins in mind into a plugin architecture is a lot of work!

True. But it is also true that attempting to generalize an API before you have three or so different targets is unwise. I'd be wary about trying to make _everything_ pluggable from the start, but thinking in terms of extension points as we build out core APIs is still a good idea.

Yeah, that's a good point. We should probably build out the v0 featureset (collect signals from Git & GitHub, keep track of cred) before designing the plugin apis, while keeping plugin design in mind. Then once we have 2-4 targets, we can start to factor them into plugins. We'll also need to give some good thought into the shared data model, and the shared UI around that data model.

Summarizing discussion with @wchargin, and brain dumping the current state of the plan:

We're planning on implementing a generic graph data structure as described in https://github.com/sourcecred/sourcecred/issues/29#issuecomment-368397367, with initial implementation in https://github.com/sourcecred/sourcecred/pull/34. The graph will provide the basis for plugin integrations: plugins create their own nodes and edges, as appropriate. As you can see in #34, each node and edge can have a custom "payload", which is determined by the plugin that generated those nodes and edges.

Plugins will also provide their own rendering and organization logic to the credgraph visualizer, as described in #39.

A few plugins which I expect we'll develop soon:
- the GitHub plugin, which sources information from GitHub interactions (#40)
- the "project" plugin, which organizes contributions into logical projects (#41)
- the npm plugin, which explores package.json dependencies within node projects (#42)
Closing this issue, because we've begun sketching out the plugin system in code and there isn't much added value from the context here.

Note that TensorBoard didn't design a plugin system until other folks started writing plugins for us. Our plugin system was a reaction that attempted to formalize the direction we saw the software evolving.

I like it when software starts off as an ordered anarchy. A highly precise and correct simple thing that folks can easily understand and lets them run free and do whatever they want. Then we bolt on design to reel back in the trouble.

In the past, we were expecting to have relatively hard barriers between different projects. Each project would issue its own cred, which would be a distinct exchangeable cryptoasset; within this view, it made sense to start with a top-down view that begins at the project root and progresses down to subprojects, and then directly to contributions. 

Now, I'm thinking of SourceCred as more of a "web-of-contributions", in which the underlying data structure is just a directed graph. There are three kinds of nodes: *projects*, *contributions*, and *identities*. 

A *project* is an attempt to make an easy entry point for recognizing the value provided by a set of contributions. It has directed edges (or, transitively, paths) to all of the contributions that compose the project. For example, I expect `SourceCred`, `SourceCred/explorer`, and `SourceCred/explorer/infrastructure` to all be projects. `/infrastructure` would have edges to the PRs that set up frontend infrastructure, like #22 and #27. `explorer/` would have edges to `explorer/infrastructure`, and so forth. 

A *contribution* is something that adds value to the project. It's a deliberately broad concept; in the case of SourceCred, I expect pull requests, issues, issue comments, Git commits, and giving talks could all be contributions. Contributions have edges to things they depend on. For example, let's consider #27. I imagine it having edges to:
- The two PRs that it directly references, which are the actual bugfixes we want merged
- @wchargin, for merging the PR
- @dandelionmane, for reviewing and merging the PR
- the SourceCred/infrastructure project, since it builds on the rest of the infrastructure in the SC frontend, and wouldn't have any value absent that context

As a consequence of those edges, it will likely also have paths to:
- babel-plugin-flow-react, because it points to two PRs in that project
- flow, via babel-plugin-flow-react
- react, as above
- babel, as above
- itself, via SourceCred/infrastructure (cycles will be *very* common)

Also, I think SourceCred/infrastructure should point to SourceCred/ root, because SourceCred frontend infrastructure derives its value from being useful to SourceCred as a whole, and if someone else e.g. makes a massive contribution to the SourceCred backend infrastructure, it makes the SC frontend infra more valuable as well.

Also, I think another path from #27 to SC/root would be via the PRs in babel-plugin-flow-react, e.g. https://github.com/brigand/babel-plugin-flow-react-proptypes/pull/182. That PR, which provides value to b-p-f-r, exists because the SourceCred project decided to use b-p-f-r, and people primarily focused on SC went and fixed it for them. So I think there's a real sense in which the SC project (or maybe more immediately: sc/explorer/infra) has contributed value to babel-plugin-flow-react.

Moving on: an *identity* is an agent or actor that deserves cred for contributing value. Identities can have edges to other identities, projects, and contributions; for example, it might make sense to create a "team identity" that has edges to the members of the team; this might be a good way to capture the value of e.g. managers, who don't directly create many recognizable contributions but let a group of people work more effectively. Also, identities may want to recognize that they derive value from other projects; for example, if I use Ubuntu and XMonad, I may want to flow value to those two projects.

(Aside: I think in the future we'll want "scoped identities" that are scoped to projects or other contexts. Hypothetically, when I make a contribution to sc/explorer/infra, by default I want to flow value to a vim-react plugin, but when I make a contribution to sc/design/incentives, I want to flow value to the authors of an open-source game theory textbook. These are future considerations.)

This graph gets weird in a recursive way when you consider that the graph, itself, is a contribution. For example, if I do a bunch of housekeeping work on the SourceCred/Explorer project (e.g. I discover a lot of important contributions that weren't acknowledged by the project, but according to our practices on maintaining the top level projects, they should have been), then that modification to the cred graph is itself a contribution that merits some cred. I'm not sure how to model that, exactly.

Question: Does this seem like a good semantic fit for the task of attributing credit to projects? Do you agree with the examples in the case of SourceCred?

If we provisionally accept the data model I described above: I think it's helpful to next explore what kinds of questions we want to answer. I think we want to assess the value provided by a {project, contribution, identity} in a way that is consistent across different contexts. Here are some examples questions within this framework:

- How valuable is the React project, in general? (~ Relative to all other projects globally, how valuable is React?)
- How valuable is the React project to SourceCred? (~ Relative to all other projects or dependencies, how much value did React contribute?)
- How valuable was #22 to the SourceCred project? How does its value compare to #21?
- How much value has @dandelionmane contributed to open-source projects in general? How much have they contributed to SourceCred? How much have they contributed in the context of frontend projects across the ecosystem? (Is there a way to define a meta "frontend-project" which can be used to measure generic "frontend-cred", as abstracted across individual projects?)

I think we need a function that takes a set of nodes that we want to value (e.g. the set of all projects and contributions that constitute React) and a set of nodes that is the scope for evaluation (e.g. the set of all projects and contributions that constitute SourceCred), and the function returns a scalar value. I.e. 

`C :: Set(Node) -> Set(Node) -> Number`

I think `C` should have the following properties:
- The amount of cred attributed to a set of contributions should be the sum of the cred attributed to the contributions within that set, after accounting for duplication. Formally, if `A` and `B` are sets of contributions and `` is an arbitrary context, then:
If `AB=U` and `AB=I` then `C(A,) + C(B,) - C(Y,) = C(X,)`

- The amount of cred attributed to a set of contributions across all contexts should be equal to the sum of the cred attributed to those contributions in every particular context, after accounting for duplication. Formally, if `A` and `B` are sets of contributions acting as a context, and `` is an arbitrary set of contributions being valued, then:
If `AB=U` and `AB=I` then `C(,A) + C(,B) - C(,I) = C(,U)`.

I believe these properties include the transparency result, in that when we look at the cred attributed to any node, we can meaningfully decompose that cred into the contexts that originated it - e.g. someone's cred in X project may be the sum of their cred in X/backend and X/frontend.

A few other properties we will want:

- Resistant to gaming by projects, e.g. the total cred allocated to SourceCred should not be meaningfully modifiable by SourceCred adding or removing internal edges. (Need some more thought to formalize this.)

- Respects graph transitivity, e.g. if `X` is a high cred node, and `X` has a high weight edge to `Y` and few other edges, then `Y` should be a reasonably high cred node.

Also, trivially:
`C(,X) = 0` and `C(X, ) = 0`.
The core data models are sufficiently designed, such that we don't need this issue to be open.

For context, here is a rough dump of the conversation that @dandelionmane and I had, leading to this issue.

If a `Node` has `address` and `payload`, and an `Edge` additionally has `src` and `dst`, then structurally `Edge` is an (inexact) subtype of `Node`. For instance, if your types are inexact, then Flow wont complain if you try to use an edge as a node.

If we want to recognize that careful valuations are themselves valuable, then it kind of makes sense to be able to flow value to a valuation: i.e., have an edge to an edge.

If edges are nodes, then the types can be unified to something like
```js
export type Entity<T> = {|
  +address: Address,
  +payload: T,
  +hom: ?{| +src: Address, +dst: Address |},
|};
```
where the `src` and `dst` addresses are for any entity.

This also suggests that the address space should be unified, which is something that we had been wondering about previously.

If edges are nodes, then its not clear how standard graph algorithms work. But there is a splicing translation from -graphs ( good name for the edges are nodes data structure) to graphs, something like the following: if an edge `e : a  b` has an incident 2-edge `f : u  e`, then make a new node ``, replace the edge `e` with edges `e_1 : a  ` and `e_2 :   b`, and change the edge `f` to be `f : u  `. Its certainly not clear that the semantics of this translation are what we want, thoughits not even clear what the semantics that we want _are_.

Using an -graph instead of a graph makes the resulting structure harder to understand at a glance.

Note that the splicing transformation described above also yields useful semantics for hyperedges (edges with multiple sources or destinations), which is something else that we had considered and rejected.

Let's call "meta-valuation" the problem of assigning value to the work of assigning value. The motivation for making edges nodes is that it provides a seemingly principled solution to the meta-valuation problem. However, as @wchargin's discussion demonstrates, it also adds a lot of complexity to our underlying data structure. Also, when you look at the semantics closely, valuing edges rarely seems like the right thing to do. Most edges are programmatically generated by some tool, e.g. the GitHub plugin automatically generates edges that represent comment authorship or cross-reference. Rewarding the individual edge that effects cross-reference seems like a very indirect way to approach meta-valuation, since really we should be rewarding contributions to the tool that generated those edges.

In #41 I describe an "artifact" plugin that creates nodes that represent curated allocations of value to pieces and processes that compose a project. The each artifact has a meta-artifact which values the work of maintaining the artifact. I believe that artifacts and meta-artifacts make significant progress towards solving meta-valuation:

- For valuing auto-generated edges, the project itself should value artifact that auto-generates those edges. For example, if SourceCred values the GitHub value network, it should flow some Cred to the artifacts that maintain that network. (Precise semantics still need clarification).

My belief is that the artifact system, or followon developments, will allow us to solve the meta-valuation problem without needing to make every edge into a node. I think that even if we need to invent some clever abstractions or practices to make it all work, it will be better than taking on an significant complexity cost in our core data structure.

@wchargin if you find this persuasive, then let's close the issue

> This factor will increase as addresses get longer in proportion to the payloads, and indeed for our `advancedMealGraph` the addresses are reasonably short.

A thought: plugins, or the Graph class itself, could choose to SHA-3 (or similar) the string-form keys to save space in the address table, if desired. This could have significant space savings for keys that are `JSON.stringify(someComplexStructure)`, at the cost of some time.

Given these two options, I prefer the object approach. It has better semantics: the way we think of the graph is that it actually *is* a map in which nodes have unique keys, and so storing it this way matches what the data structure actually means.

However, it is redundant, because we essentially have a `Map k (k, v)`.

An aside on types. We had an offline discussion about how we want to set up our `Node` type: do we want to express subtyping by saying `Node`s have a payload with subtype, or `Node`s are extended to the subtype? I.e.:

Payload Approach:
```ts
type Node<T> {
  address: Address,
  payload: T,
}

type IssuePayload {
  title: string,
}

type IssueNode = Node<IssuePayload>
```

Extension Approach:

```ts
type Node {
  address: Address,
}

type IssueNode extends Node {
  title: string,
}
```

We decided to go with the payload approach; both because it's considered best practice to prefer composition over inheritance, and because it creates a data structure that explicitly reflects how our data is composed (ie: everything from plugin is under payload/, rather than plugin data is mixed in at the same level).

However, when you consider the Edge type:

```ts
type Edge<T> {
  address: Address,
  src: Address,
  dst: Address,
  payload: T,
}
```

It starts to look like both Edge and Node are implicitly inheriting from an undeclared base type Addressable:

```ts
type Addressable {
  address: Address,
}
```

While writing test code, we've actually reified the Addressable type a few times, which suggests that it's a useful concept. 

Would it be useful to factor out `Addressable`s as a payload-bearing-type like we did with `Node` and `Edge`? E.g. 

```ts
type Addressable<T> {
  address: Address,
  payload: T,
}
```

Except really I think we can more clearly express ourselves by understanding that the semantics we want from addresses are really just key-value semantics, where the keys are arbitrary JSON-serializable objects, and as an implementation detail, we can easily generate a map over Addressables by JSON-stringifying the key.

```ts
type Addressable<T> {
  key: JSONSerialiazable,
  value: T,
}
```
If we factor things like this, I think there's a very natural answer to "how should AddressableMaps be serialized": when JSON serializing, we stringify the keys, and elide them from the objects to avoid redundant encoding. When deserializing, we parse the keys into Address objects so that consumers can read the addresses as expected. 

Basically, this whole structure is an abstraction over a bug, where the bug is that you can't use JSON objects as keys in js maps.

> It starts to look like both Edge and Node are implicitly inheriting from an undeclared base type Addressable: [] While writing test code, we've actually reified the Addressable type a few times, which suggests that it's a useful concept.

Agreed. It could also make sense to make it an interface:

(This appeals to me in part because weve had lots of trouble getting Flow to work as expected with intersection types and similar. Also, semantically it _is_ an interface.)
   
> Would it be useful to factor out `Addressable`s as a payload-bearing-type like we did with Node and Edge? E.g.

I dont think so, because this doesnt work nicely for edges. What happens to `src` and `dst`? You could put them into the payload, so that
```js
type Edge<T> = Addressable<{| +src: Address, +dst: Address, +realPayload: T |}>
```
but thats quite ugly, IMO: `edge.payload.realPayload` is ungainly, and `edge.payload.src` doesnt make sense. Semantically, `src` and `dst` are _not_ part of the payload of the edge. They are metadata, like the address. But if we put them at top level, then `Edge<T>` adds additional properties onto `Addressable<T>`. This is weird, because the structure of this version of `Addressable<T>` strongly suggests that an object `x: Addressable<T>` is determined only by its `address` and its `payload`. For instance, given this interface, I would feel comfortable writing an equality function:
```js
function equals<T>(x: Addressable<T>, y: Addressable<T>) {
  return deepEqual(x.address, y.address) && deepEqual(x.payload, y.payload);
}
```
which would fail on edges.

I also dont really see any advantage to including the payload in the `Addressable` interface, so Ithink that the simple `interface Addressable { +address: Address; }` is the way to go.

You also propose an alternate interface where the `Addressable`s key is an arbitrary `JSONSerializable`. This idea sounds reasonable to me, but I would also consider putting the `JSONSerializable` on the `id` field of the `Address` type, so that all addresses are still required to have a repository and plugin name:
```js
type Address = {|
  +repositoryName: string,
  +pluginName: string,
  +id: JSONSerializable,
|};
```
This is structure that we do want in the graph, so we have to encode it somewhere. And putting it in the address is the only reasonable way that I can see to do it.

What do you think?

> where the keys are arbitrary JSON-serializable objects

After a bit more thinking and prototyping, Im less sold on this. I think that it forces a lot more serialization and deserialization than is really necessary. Any time that we need to refer to an address opaquely, well have to serialize and deserialize the plugin-specific `id`which may be arbitrarily large. For instance, a breadth-first search requires at least one roundtrip serialization for each node in the connected component of the source (and with our APIs were looking at two or three). If `Address` has `id: string`, then no such computation is performed: a plugin only parses IDs when their contents are relevant.

Using `id: string` of course _allows_ plugins to serialize the data from JSON themselves, but does not require them to. Using `id: JSONSerializable` would be convenient for the standard use case, and promote good defaults, but it _may_ be the case that it precludes efficient implementations.

Note that this is compatible with your other suggestion that we can use the JSON serialization of the Address as the object keys, and elide them from the Addressables. (And on deserialization we put them back.)

Weve spent a bunch of time talking about this, so heres what I suggest: Ill implement an address map against this spec, just so that we have something to work from, and then we can remain open to changing it latereither in response to perf requirements or because we decide that another approach is semantically better. Sound good?

Sounds good. As you say, using `id: string` allows plugins to layer in additional information, while restricting the performance cost of maintaining that additional information to the scope of the plugin that actually knows how to use the info. Generic algorithms operating at the level of a ContributionGraph shouldn't be expected to have insight into what the plugin specific ID means, so therefore they shouldn't pay the associated serialization cost.

The major problem with this is that the resulting structure is no longer serializable.

A secondary problem is that `Graph.merge` with a nontrivial node resolver becomes much more expensive: for each resolution, you need to touch all edges, or at least all incident edges.

I'm totally fine with `source`/`target` instead of `src`/`dst`.
What motivates this issue? Performance, usability, something else?

I think it could present a benefit in terms of performance (fewer map lookups on graph traversal) and usability (makes a common case more convenient). However, you make a good point that it adds complexity to our algorithms. I suggest we table this, but set ourselves up with an easy path to add it in the future if we so desire. We can do this by renaming `Edge.src` and `Edge.dst` to `Edge.srcAddress` and `Edge.dstAddress`; more verbose, but more descriptive too. This way, if we decide down the line that it would be nice to give the objects direct pointers to the nodes as well, the naming will still be consistent.

Also, I think aligning with `d3-force` on layout is a non-goal, the abstractions are pretty different anyway, so let's forget about that.

One downside/question raised by this: does this couple too closely the
logical type of an edge with the implementation type?

For instance, a GitHub comment can link to an issue by writing `#23` or
`https://github.com/owner/project/issues/23`. It is reasonable that
these should both have the type issue reference. But it is also
reasonable that the GitHub plugin might want to distinguish these
internally. (Say, the former just has `number: number`, while the latter
also has `repoOwner: string` and `repoName: string`.)

This is perhaps not a perfect example, but I think that it illustrates
the point.
The `Address` is part of the public surface area of the `Edge`. If the GitHub plugin wants to distinguish those cases internally, why would it want to reveal that distinction in the `Address`?

Logically, it wouldnt. But if it doesnt, then it has to have nodes
like this:
```js
{
    repositoryOwner: "sourcecred",
    repositoryName: "example-repo",
    type: "ISSUE_REFERENCE",
    id: id,
    payload: JSON.stringify({
        type: "NUMERIC",
        number: 23,
    }),
}
```
This is the kind of thing that I worry about. Now we have two notions of
`type`: the generic one, and the inevitable plugin-specific one because
no generic solution will always suffice. What are the remaining benefits
of the generic `type`, given that well have plugin-specific adapter
interfaces anyway?

Ive now merged PRs #118, #119, #120, #121, #122, and #123, which
collectively implement the pagination API for our particular GitHub
query (as you can tell from the commit spam above!). Here are some
things that I learned along the way and TODOs for the future.

## General foundations

The process of implementing this specific case was valuable. It is
_easier_ to see how to generalize to the general case, and this could
plausibly be done incrementally while maintaining test coverage. Its
still not trivial: for one thing, the schema is currently hard-coded in
the type of the `enclosingNodeType` attribute of the `Continuation`
type, and in the `continuationsForX` functions.

## Fold direction for continuation accumulation

Suppose that we have a sequence of three queries: the first an original
query, and the next two fetching more pages for some subfields. We might
receive the following results:
```js
const r1 = {
  repository: {
    issues: {
      pageInfo: {hasMorePages: true},
      nodes: [/* issue #1 */],
    },
  },
};
const r2 = {
  _n7: {
    issues: {
      pageInfo: {hasMorePages: true},
      nodes: [/* issue #2 */],
    },
  },
};
const r3 = {
  _n3: {
    issues: {
      pageInfo: {hasMorePages: false},
      nodes: [/* issue #3 */],
    },
  },
};
```

We need to combine these. We have two options: we could combine `r1` and
`r2` to form
```js
const r12 = {
  repository: {
    issues: {
      pageInfo: {hasMorePages: true},
      nodes: [/* issue #1 */, /* issue #2 */],
    },
  },
};
```
and then merge `r3` into this to form our final result, or we could
start by combining `r2` and `r3` thus:
```js
const r23 = {
  _n7: {
    issues: {
      pageInfo: {hasMorePages: true},
      nodes: [/* issue #2 */, /* issue #3 */],
    },
  },
};
```

This can roughly be seen as varying the associativity of the merge
operation: the former option has left-associative merge, and the latter
operator right-associative merge.

The left-associative merge has the advantage that at each step the
result is a sensible response to the original query that becomes
incrementally more complete. This makes it easier to gradually display
more information in a UI, or to pick up where we left off if we are
interrupted. The right-associative merge is more computationally
efficient, because we are always operating on small structures until the
very end, instead of operating on a megastructure at each step.

Which strategy is used is an implementation detail, so theres nothing
pressing here, but we should keep an eye on it. Currently, we use a
variant of the left-associative merge. In fact, our process is to
generate `r12` and analyze _it_ for continuations to form the query that
yields `r3`, instead of getting these directly from `r2`. This is
especially computationally wasteful, so improving this (while keeping
the merge left-associative) should be our first step if client-side
performance becomes an issue.

## Typing for queries and results

This is an interesting one. In [a comment][comment-flow-types] on #76,
@decentralion proposed that we generate Flow types for the _results_ of
GraphQL queries. If we had had this infrastructure when I was writing
the specific implementation, then a few mistakes that I made would have
been mitigated. Others, that could be caught in principle, would not:
for instance, at one point I declared something like
```js
const subpath = [...path, "issues", i];
```
where I should have written
```js
const subpath = [...path, "issues", "nodes", i];
```
but it is not possible\* to express the semantics of the logical type of
`path` in a Flow type (e.g., that `result.issues.nodes[i]` should be
defined in the above example).

However, I believe that these benefits would be mostly lost if we moved
to the more general API (still GitHub-specific, but not query-specific).
Also, I think that the marginal value of these types _once the
pagination API is already written_ (and never changed again or
refactored, of course! :-) ) is small. The top-level APIs types are
very simple and do not depend on any particular schema types. Therefore,
my conclusion is that my needle on whether we should add GraphQL result
types hasnt actually moved much at all as a result of performing this
work.

\* Certainly not possible without tricky tricks. Ive played around with
it and dont think that its possible at all with these value types.
Maybe some contortions would be able to force it, but I suspect that it
would not be worth the trouble.

[comment-flow-types]: https://github.com/sourcecred/sourcecred/issues/76#issuecomment-373613940

## Relay Cursor Connections Specification

GitHubs GraphQL API implements the [Relay Cursor Connections
Specification][spec]. It would therefore be feasible to write our more
general pagination API against this spec, so that it could be more
easily applicable to other projects. Theres one catch: GitHub provides
some syntactic sugar that is not required by the spec, but which we use
extensively. In particular:

  - The `nodes` fields on connections are not required; only the `edges`
    fields are. Of course, `nodes {  }` can always be replaced with
    `edges { node {  } }`, but this changes the structure of the output
    by introducing an additional level of nesting.

  - The `PageInfo` type is not required to expose `endCursor` and
    `startCursor`; instead, cursor are provided via `edges { cursor }`.
    Here, `data.pageInfo.endCursor` is approximately equivalent to
    `data.edges[data.edges.length - 1].cursor`, modulo error handling.

This presents the following options.

  - Write the pagination API against an extension of the GraphQL spec
    that also requires these extensions. (Before selecting this, it
    would be a good idea to find other implementors of the Relay spec
    and see if they provide a similar affordance. The [examples] in
    the Relay docs have `endCursor` but not `nodes`, for instance.)

  - Write the pagination API against the vanilla Relay spec, and change
    our data format accordingly. This would cause a bit of bloat in the
    output data, but probably not significantly.

  - Write some kind of hybrid that fetches according to the spec but
    then transforms the data into our currently-expected format. (This
    doesnt seem like a good idea to me.)

[spec]: https://facebook.github.io/relay/graphql/connections.htm
[examples]: https://facebook.github.io/relay/docs/en/graphql-server-specification.html#schema

## Long-term plan

This whole module is predicated on the assumption that recursively
fetching the whole repository is the right thing to do. This scales well
to small, medium, and even large-ish projects, but not to the outliers:
for instance, torvalds/linux has 750,000 commits. Eventually, well need
to make sure to use online algorithms everywhere. But thats a task for
another time.

Im closing this issue for now. When we want to extend the pagination
API, we can create a new issue and link it hence.
(But feel free to continue discussing here!)

Here is one idea: nodes are arbitrary JSON blobs with a `type`
identifier; plugins register handlers that take nodes of a fixed `type`
to a unique address.

In more detail, suppose that we define nodes as follows (names up for
discussion):
```js
interface Node {
  +__type: {|
    +repositoryName: string,
    +pluginName: string,
    +type: string,
  |};
}
```
Then, a plugin can register a handler:
```
type Id = string;
interface AddressHandler<T> {
  (node: Node<T>): Id;
}
type AddressHandlers = {[type: string]: AddressHandler};
```

For simple nodes, this can just be a projection:
```js
type Commit: Node = {|
  +__type: {|
    +repositoryName: string,
    +pluginName: "sourcecred/git-beta",
    +type: "COMMIT",
  |},
  +hash: string,
  +summary: string,
|};
function handleCommit(commit: Commit) {
  // Commits can be uniquely identified by hash.
  return commit.hash;
}
```
Something more complicated, like `JSON.stringify(someFieldsOfNode)`,
might be necessary for more complicated nodes.

In some sense, this addressing function can be considered an
optimization, because `JSON.stringify(theWholeNode)` should always be a
safe (i.e., injective) implementation. This implementation has a few
downsides, though. First, memory performance: using a commits full
summary, or a blobs full contents, as an address will lead to a lot of
wasted space. This is especially true for nodes with lots of incident
edges. Second, decreased lookup potential: using `handleCommit` above,
one can write
```js
graph.node(gitPlugin.commitNodeAddress(someHash)).summary
```
to find the summary of a commit for which only the hash is known. (This
pattern obviously generalizes.) If the content-addressing requires the
whole object, then this is no longer feasible. It could be argued that
this is not inherently bad, that a graph is not necessarily supposed to
be a keyvalue store.

Lots of details remain to be filled in, of course. Thoughts welcome.

I like this proposal, and am open to implementing it soon (and, as ever, we can try it out and see how we like it in practice).

One addition: I think we should get rid of the `repositoryName` field. In cases where the repositoryName is actually needed to disambiguate, the projector logic can be responsible for inserting it, but in many cases (e.g. Git and GitHub plugins), it seems unnecessary.

I think what we were aiming for with the repositoryName field was really something more like: `publisher`, i.e. which entity has responsibility for updating this information / can canonically provide the source of truth? However, conflating that with repository boundaries needlessly complicates cross-repository projects. For now, I think we can assume that all graphs exist in the purview of a single publisher (the entity that created it) and we can hold off on adding publisher-type information until the requirements are clear.

It's confusing that GitHub apparently has two different ways to die on large GraphQL requests: either the "unknown error (possibly timeout)" that we were seeing prior to https://github.com/sourcecred/sourcecred/pull/349, or this failure.

I think the situation here would be substantially improved if we cache the GitHub response (inc. continuation queries) to disk as it's generated. That would have two consequences:

1. On the user's first request to a large repo, it may fail. However, since they will have cached a bunch of data received prior to triggering this mechanism, they will still have made progress. Running the program a few more times will eventually get them into a good state. This is much better than the status quo, where if it doesn't Just Work you're pretty much stuck.
2. Once they're in a good state, subsequent runs will just pick up new activity via the continuation query, which will result in much better performance, less stress on GitHub, and will avoid this failure

@decentralion: Here are my thoughts on your proposal.

First of all: I like it. It seems like clearly a good thing to do.

Second: it seems that this kind of data (partial results and
continuations) should be stored in a plugin-specific data directory, so
well want some simple abstraction for that.

Third: I note that the proposal assumes that the queries will fetch a
consistent state of the repository over multiple requests. This is of
course not true in general. Now, this assumption is already present in
the current version of the code, basically by necessity: we cant
instruct GitHub to commit a DB snapshot, for obvious reasons, so this is
just another design constraint that we have to consider. But the model
described in your point (2) greatly increases the strength of the
assumption: were assuming that results from a repository are
conservative extensions of not just very recent results but also
results at arbitrary times in the past. This changes the game from if
your queries are fast enough and your repository isnt being touched
every second, youre probably okay to sooner or later, someone _will_
delete a comment in the repository (or make some other incompatible
change), at which point youre out of luck. This may motivate us to
devise some intermediate format that is robust to such modifications.
For instance, currently the continuation queries have associated
structures like, run this continuation, then merge it into element 17
of `results.repository.issues.nodes` or whatever. Replacing indexing
with some more stable content address (issue number, unique pull request
review ID, etc.) could improve robustness.

Fourth: there are two degrees to which we could implement the proposal,
which vary in difficulty. Implementing point (1) of your list is
reasonably tractable: once we have the plugin-specific data directory
working, this change should probably be about a days work. But your
point (2) is a bit harder. Currently, when a query returns with
`hasNextPage: false`, we consume the relevant continuation, because we
have found all relevant data. The model that you propose requires
keeping around these continuations and querying them again when we want
to check for updates to the graph. This is certainly possible, but will
take some doingespecially if we want to be robust to long-term
backward-incompatible changes, as described above.

Finally, and related only indirectly to this conversation: as we make
the GraphQL logic more complex, we may want to keep in mind the option
of autogenerating Flow types from the GraphQL schema.

One thing you may also want to consider in the future if you're trying to pull in more data across GitHub: starting with a graph populated by continual updates from gharchive https://www.gharchive.org/

If you already know all the issues and base level information and just need to get comments or other leaf data out of GraphQL there's some tricks you can do with the search API to run those sub-queries across 100 specific issues or repos or people all at once by creating a large search string with each one.

### Plugin Specific Directories

I agree; the `Git` plugin would benefit even more from caching its
results than the GitHub plugin does. (I believe we would not have
consistency issues?)

### Consistency issues

In the long term, if this system is to be decentralized, we can't avoid
thinking about consistency issues. Within individual scopes it's
possible to maintain consistency; across scopes (e.g. plugin boundaries)
it's much harder. 

It would be interesting to have a design discussion about how to handle
consistency problems in general. The space of possible
solutions is very large; for example, making a blockchain would be one
way to do it. But that would introduce enormous complexity which is
incidental to SourceCred's present goals, so: let's not :)

The core algorithms will need to be accommodating of cases where
consistency has been violated. I think we can do this in a generalizable
way by handling all reconciliation when merging graphs, so that any
graph can be considered internally consistent. Then we can provide
scoped resolvers that can use plugin-specific logic to accommodate their
own inconsistencies.

As other plugins begin interacting more richly with the GitHub plugin,
we'll need to solve consistency for the GitHub plugin. But for now, we
_could_ punt on it.

I would really like if we can get to a solution that is robust, even if
not fully correct. That is, when underlying consistency is violated, it
may show locally corrupted / inconsistent data, but the data still
loads, displays the same UI, approximately the same PageRank. 

Then we can implement the GitHub plugin caching with a ~24 hour TTL,
which I think will minimize the rate of consistency problems, and also
make the software feel far more performant. 

Alternatively: we can implement the caching purely at the CLI layer;
rather than getting true incremental querying, we could just cache the
result of `sourcecred graph foo bar` with a 24hr TTL. I guess this would
manifest similar performance benefits with a fraction of the
implementation complexity. Then we can focus instead on actually
developing credit attribution. :)

### Autogenerating flow types for GraphQL

I think this is pretty low priority. The manual process seems fine to
me. We're unlikely to merge many bugs because Flow will complain at type
usage even if it wasn't added properly at source. And at our current
rate of GraphQL query modification, the labor savings from automating it
will not be significant.

@mikeal the important thing to us with the GitHub API is that it's possible to query just for an individual repository or organization's data in an efficient fashion. That makes it feasible to not have any central SourceCred servers, and instead have all the users get their own copy of the data from GitHub (in the future, from IPFS). It seems to me that the gh-archive won't be very useful in this model, because individual users won't want to download the whole history of GitHub in order to analyze the particular project they're participating in.

This would allow individual nodes to subscribe to information about specific repos or orgs in the future and could seed your data needs without dealing with GitHub rate limits. Once this gets off the ground a bit more I'll ping you to make sure that we include all the information you need as we filter a lot of the noise out in the pipeline.

Regarding softbreaks: as far as I can tell, the GitHub markdown renderer is not actually a conformant implementation of GitHub Flavored Markdown. The [GFM spec for soft line breaks][GFM-slb] has the same contents as the [CommonMark spec for soft line breaks][CM-slb]; both say: > A regular line break (not in a code span or HTML tag) that is not > preceded by two or more spaces or a backslash is parsed as a > **softbreak**. (A softbreak may be rendered in HTML either as a line > ending or as a space. The result will be the same in browsers. In the > examples here, a line ending will be used.) where line ending is defined (identically) in both specs: > A line ending is a newline (`U+000A`), a carriage return (`U+000D`) > not followed by a newline, or a carriage return and a following > newline. [GFM-slb]: https://github.github.com/gfm/#soft-line-breaks [CM-slb]: https://spec.commonmark.org/0.28/#soft-line-breaks GitHubs markdown renderer renders a softbreak as a `
` elemnent, which is neither a line ending nor a space (and, consequently, GitHub renders all my Markdown incorrectly). In the implementation of this commit, I will follow the behavior of the CommonMark spec.

As of #480, we have rudimentary Markdown parsing: notably, we now
properly ignore code blocks (fixing some false positives) and properly
interpret softbreaks as spaces (fixing some false negatives).

The next step is to properly handle links. In the current system (as of
#480), link destinations are ignored entirely, and link text is treated
as normal text. I chose this design because it is simple to understand
and implement, and I preferred to get a simple version of Markdown
working rather than turn on a complicated system from scratch. Now that
we have a simple system, we can improve it to handle links better.

Below I describe how we might approach such a change. I note upfront
that improving the reference parsing to properly handle links is
probably not at the top of our current priorities, so Im happy to defer
this discussion and/or implementation to another time.

## Common URL templates

To understand the situation, we should take a look at some sample
inputs, their GitHub-rendered output, and their CommonMark AST.

### Template: raw URL

Example:

```markdown
Consider visiting https://example.com/ for great good.
```

GitHub renders the inline URL as a link, per the [extension to autolinks
defined in the GitHub Flavored Markdown spec][gfm-autolink-ext].

[gfm-autolink-ext]: https://github.github.com/gfm/#autolinks-extension-

The base CommonMark spec does not classify raw URLs as links.
Correspondingly, the [AST for a raw URL][ast-raw] has only a `text`
node.

[ast-raw]: https://spec.commonmark.org/dingus/?text=Consider%20visiting%20https%3A%2F%2Fexample.com%2F%20for%20great%20good.%0A

### Template: autolinked URL

Example:

```markdown
Consider visiting <https://example.com/> for great good.
```

GitHub and [CommonMark][ast-autolink] both render this as a URL with
anchor text the same as the destination. That is, the URL appears twice
in the AST: once as the `destination` attribute of the link, and once as
raw text in its body.

[ast-autolink]: https://spec.commonmark.org/dingus/?text=Consider%20visiting%20%3Chttps%3A%2F%2Fexample.com%2F%3E%20for%20great%20good.%0A

### Template: link reference

Example:

```markdown
Consider visiting [this website][1] for great good.

[1]: https://example.com/
```

GitHub and [CommonMark][ast-reference] both render this as a URL with
the expected semantics. In particular, the URL appears only once in the
AST: in the `destination` attribute of the link.

[ast-reference]: https://spec.commonmark.org/dingus/?text=Consider%20visiting%20%5Bthis%20website%5D%5B1%5D%20for%20great%20good.%0A%0A%5B1%5D%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fexample.com%2F%0A

### Template: repeated link reference

Example:

```markdown
Consider [visiting][1] this [website][1] for great good.

[1]: https://example.com/
```

GitHub and [CommonMark][ast-repeated] both render this as URLs with
the expected semantics. In particular, the URL appears twice in the AST:
once in the `destination` attribute of each link.

[ast-repeated]: https://spec.commonmark.org/dingus/?text=Consider%20%5Bvisiting%5D%5B1%5D%20this%20%5Bwebsite%5D%5B1%5D%20for%20great%20good.%0A%0A%5B1%5D%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fexample.com%2F%0A

## Analysis

The current system, as of #480, detects both raw URLs and autolinked
URLs exactly once each, because the URL appears exactly once in the
text. But it does not detect explicit links, because the URL does not
appear in the text. This is a problem worth fixing.

## Proposal

Consider the following modifications to the current system:

  - Modify the spec of `deformat` such that it does not collapse link
    text into the surrounding context.

  - Modify the spec of `textBlocks` such that it returns not `string[]`
    but `TextBlock[]`, where `TextBlock` is a discriminated union:

    ```js
    type TextBlock =
      | {|+type: "TEXT", +value: string|}
      | {|+type: "LINK_DESTINATION", +value: string|};
    ```

    When processing a link, the new `textBlocks` would ignore the link
    text entirely, emitting only a `LINK_DESTINATION` block.

  - Modify `parseReferences` such that it processes the blocks as
    follows:
      - For `TEXT` blocks, all types of references (including URL
        references) are parsed.
      - For `LINK_DESTINATION` blocks, only URL references are parsed.

Here are some effects of the resulting system:

  - Raw URLs are still parsed, because the URL will appear in a text
    block and be parsed accordingly.
  - Autolinked URLs are still parsed (exactly once), due to the link
    destination.
  - Explicit links are now parsed once per occurrence. For instance, in
    the repeated link reference example above, two references to
    `https://example.com/` will be identified. I believe that this is
    the correct behavior: the body does, in fact, have two references.
    (Downstream clients can of course deduplicate this if they choose.)
  - In a link like `[see #32 and #33](https://example.com/)`, the issue
    references `#32` and `#33` are no longer parsed. I tentatively
    believe that this is a good thingit is strange that a link should
    be said to refer to things other than its destinationbut I am
    willing to be convinced otherwise.
  - In a link like `[@decentralion](https://github.com/decentralion)`,
    we only detect one username reference (by URL, not by `@`-handle).
    I tentatively believe that this is a good thing: semantically, there
    is only one reference.
  - In `[Paired with @decentralion](https://github.com/decentralion)`,
    we detect a URL-based username reference, but not a paired-with
    reference. Similarly, in `[Paired][1] with @decentralion`, we do not
    detect a paired-with reference.

All consequences except for the last one seem positive to me. The last
one is probably a bad thing. However, I dont see a semantics that
offers strictly better behavior on all cases. For instance, we could
properly detect this paired-with reference by parsing all references
inside `LINK_DESTINATION` blocks, but this causes many other cases to
misbehave: e.g., autolinks generate multiple references.

I think that Id like to accept the imperfection due to the last point
and switch to this system: the benefit of parsing `[explicit links][1]`
outweighs, in my mind, the false negatives in the cases where we
actually want to have multiple overlapping references.

cc @decentralion; thoughts appreciated.

What follows are some late-night thoughts, based on having taken a stab at writing a `PluginAdapterCollection` class. 

I notice there's some redundancy between `plugins` and `types`:
- They both have names
- They both have prefixes
- While only the `plugin` has a `nodeDescription` method, internally that method effectively delegates to the types (switch over type).

What if we unify them into a shared recursive abstraction: (note: I'm writing only for nodes, but assume there will be corresponding types for edges too)

```js
type NodeType = {|
  +name: string,
  +prefix: NodeAddressT,
  +description: (NodeAddressT) => string,
  +render: (NodeAddressT) => React.Component,
  +weight: (NodeAddressT) => NodeWeight,
|}

interface PluginAdapter {|
  +name: string,
  +edgeTypes: EdgeType[],
  +nodeTypes: NodeType[],
  +graph: () => Graph,
|}
```

There can also be a `BaseNodeType`:
```js
const baseNodeType = {
name: "[base type]",
prefix: NodeAddress.empty,
description: (n) => NodeAddress.toString(n),
...
```

Then, when finding the right method for a given node address, we choose the most specific Type available (and the presence of the BaseNodeType ensures that we always find a type). It is illegal to have multiple types with the exact same prefix. 

As written, the types have all kinds of stuff attached (render, weight, etc), but clearly we should factor that out. The core type abstraction should probably just have a name and a prefix and description function (for error messages, etc). And we should find a way to have interfaces for extending the Type concept with additional requirements, e.g. adding the react-based render method.

The advantage over this compared to the current approach is it allows "plugins" and "sub-plugins" and "sub-sub-plugins" rather than forcing all extensibility to occur at the base level of the tree.

@wchargin what do you think?

Cool; I like this. I was going to take a stab at implementing this, but
it sounds like you have a lot of context/prior work on it, so Ill hold
off on doing so.

> They both have names

Note that names of plugins could _arguably_ be required to be unique
(though I wouldnt be thrilled about this), but names of types are
definitely not unique. Concepts of user, issue, comment will be
shared across lots of plugins. (No change required.)

> What if we unify them into a shared recursive abstraction

I dont see how the abstraction that you propose is recursive. What do
you mean by that?

> Then, when finding the right method for a given node address, we choose the most specific Type available (and the presence of the BaseNodeType ensures that we always find a type).

I like the idea of having the base node type being a fallback on the
same level of everything else.

> It is illegal to have multiple types with the exact same prefix.

Yes, agreed. Perhaps we should also require that if `t1` is a child type
of `t0` (e.g., `t1` is a node type and `t0` is a plugin), then the
prefix of `t0` is a prefix of the prefix of `t1`. (That is, the function
from node types to node prefixes is a poset homomorphism.) Then, it is
possible to ensure that all types have distinct prefixes by reasoning
locally: you only have to consider your siblings, not all other types at
all levels, and in particular it will be valid to combine any set of
plugins as long as their _top-level_ prefixes are pairwise disjoint.

> `type NodeType`

Multiple functions of the `NodeType` (`render`, `weight`, at least) will
need to take more context than just a single node addressthe graph, at
the very least, plus maybe some additional context (e.g., the GitHub
plugins relational view). But it sounds like youre suggesting that the
node types be constants, as opposed to (e.g.) creating the GitHub node
types for a particular repository owner and name, receiving a
`Promise<NodeType[]>` in return. How is this resolved?

> As written, the types have all kinds of stuff attached (render,
> weight, etc), but clearly we should factor that out.

Agreed, though Im willing to do this as needed.

Another idea, based on some discussions with @wchargin:

Often times, consumers of the static adapter actually want the data in this type:
```
export type PluginDescription = {|
  +nodePrefix: NodeAddressT,
  +edgePrefix: EdgeAddressT,
  +name: string,
  +nodeTypes: $ReadOnlyArray<NodeType>,
  +edgeTypes: $ReadOnlyArray<EdgeType>,
|}
```

Interestingly, this is almost exactly the static adapter, minus the `load` method. As such, I now think it would be nice to refactor the adapters into two classes: `UnloadedAdapter` and `LoadedAdapter`.
The loaded adapter would provide dynamically available methods like the `nodeDescription`, `graph`, - basically it absorbs the DynamicAdapter. It would also have a method to retrieve the `pluginDescription` type defined above, and an `unload` method in case you need an UnloadedAdapter. The `UnloadedAdapter` would provide a method to get the `pluginDescription` data type above, and provide a `load`method for getting the `LoadedAdapter`.

Basically, this factors away the parts of the static adapter that just provide data, from the part that is responsible for loading a dynamic adapter. This is convenient as many consumers of the static adapter's data don't need the extra complexity of being able to load the adapter, and having that complexity around makes it less convenient to test consumers of the static adapter.

Also, moving away from an interface to a simple data type will be convenient.

Will need to make a corresponding refactor to the adapter sets, so as to create a PluginDescriptionSet or such, with intelligent use of Tries.

doesnt seem to have huge concrete advantages.

We like the idea of log-space priors, because its a natural space in
which to think. But the semantics for composing them as described above
dont have the properties that we want.

First, lets make the above semantics a bit more precise. Assume that we
only consider finite, inhabited types. Then:

  - A `LogDist ` is a total map from `` to `Real` whose image is
    centered around `0`.

  - A `Dist ` is a valid probability distribution on ``, represented
    as a function `f :   NonnegativeReal` with the constraint that
    `sum (values f) == 1`.

  - We have `extend :  , . ( <: )  LogDist   LogDist `, defined by

    ```
    extend f (x : ) = f x
    extend f _ = 0
    ```

  - We have `normalize :  . (  NonnegativeReal) Dist ` given by

    ```
    normalize f x = f x / total
      where total = sum (values f)
    ```

  - We have `reify :  . LogDist   Dist ` given by

    ```
    reify f = normalize (exp  f)
    ```

  - We would like to define a notion of combination of log-distributions:

    ```
    (<>) :  . LogDist   LogDist   LogDist 
    ```

  - This operation should have at least the following property:

    **Irrelevance.** If `f, g : LogDist ` and `x : `, and `f x == 0`,
    then `reify g x == reify (f <> g) x`.
    
From this formulation, there are a few things to note:

  - The implementation of `(<>)` given simply by pointwise addition does
    not satisfy the irrelevance property. It will be true that if
    `f x == 0` then `g x == (f <> g) x`, but it need not be true that
    `reify g x == reify (f <> g) x`, because the normalization factors
    in `g` and `f <> g` are, in general, different.

  - The `Dist` and `LogDist` functors are isomorphic, and in particular
    the operator `(<>)` induces an operator ` f.  g. reify (f <> g)`
    for combining non-log-space distributions. The problems are clearly
    equivalent, and while it may be more convenient to work in one space
    or the other, any fundamental problems must exist in both spaces.

  - Although `(<>)` is a simple operation in log-space, its not clear
    how to interpret this in distribution space. We can write down what
    it does, but how, intuitively, is it actually transforming the
    values? What is the interpretation?

  - The `Dist` functor happens to be a very useful monad (in my opinion,
    an underappreciated one), which already has a notion of combination
    of distributions: `join :  . Dist (Dist )  Dist `. This
    necessarily requires a prior over the distributions themselves. We
    should keep this in mind while designing our semantics: if we
    _dont_ require a prior over these distributions (as in the API for
    our `(<>)` above), then what are we doing? Are we assuming a uniform
    prior? Is that a good thing?

Suppose that we have a row-stochastic weighted adjacency matrix `M`, and
a weighting vector `w`, and let `W = diag(w)` as above. The above post
suggests setting `M = W M W`. The result of this is that an edge from
`u` to `v` with change weight from `t` to `t w(u) w(v)`. The resulting
`M` is not row-stochastic, so we have to re-normalize it, and at that
point the factor `w(u)` in its definition (i.e., the left-multiplication
by `W`) cancels out.

So, instead, we may simply define `M = row-normalize(M  diag(w))`.

It is useful to reiterate that this is equivalent to multiplying each
edges weight by `w(v)`, where `v` is the destination of the edge.

Agreed on all counts.

It all started when I wanted to add a progress bar to the PageRank
tables computation. Adding a progress bar is nice because it enables us
to use a stricter convergence threshold: we can ask users to wait longer
if we give them a reasonable estimate of how much time is remaining,
instead of just indeterminately hanging the page.

I had noticed previously that the delta parameter reported by PageRank
appeared to converge linearly in log-space. We also, by construction,
know the target value of delta. Therefore, using the log-delta would be
a great option for a linear progress bar. From here on, well define the
time-varying parameter progress to be the value `r` such that
`log(delta) = lerp(r, log(1), log(targetDelta))`.

But this had surprising results. Here is a graph of progress over time
for the first 3.5 seconds of a run that ended up taking just over two
minutes:

![plot-1]

[plot-1]: https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4317806/43302056-3ecdb6e0-911d-11e8-8ca7-374f130cfb64.png

First of all, the PageRank computation takes constant time per
stepthere are no data-dependent control flow pathsso this isnt due to
steps taking longer over time. (The data confirms this: elapsed time vs.
current step is completely linear).

Taking a closer look reveals that the graph really is piecewise-linear,
but the slope has a big discontinuity after about 1260ms.

This graph was not generated with the default (uniform) edge weights.
Indeed, the base-2-log-space edge weights used were: AUTHORS: +3.8;
MERGED_AS: 6.8, REFERENCES: +5.8; all others: 0.0. The result is that
the GitHub subgraph has lots of edges with very high and very low
transition probabilities.

Recall that the delta underlying the progress is `max(  )`. This
means that if most of the graph has converged, but tiny a subgraph is
taking a long time to converge, then the overall reported delta will
still be large.

After resetting the weights to the default (uniform) weights, PageRank
converged in 779 steps, instead of 37820 steps with the skewed weights.
This suggested that some part of the graph, probably the GitHub graph,
was holding up the rest.

[I instrumented SourceCreds PageRank to dump the full ` - ` vector
at each iteration,][gist] dumping the results in JSON to a 6.3GB log
file (1.4GB after gzip). Then, I analyzed this with `jq` to track the
proportion of the deltas that were exactly zero over time:

```shell
buf | stdbuf -o0 jq '.deltas | (map(select(. == 0)) | length) / length' | nl
```

[gist]: https://gist.github.com/wchargin/b9aef6fcc1262d6bac66231ab3da272a

(Here, `buf` is a shell alias that prints the raw log file.)

Piping that through `sed -n '25~25p'` gives:

```
    25	0
    50	0
    75	0.004107142857142857
   100	0.05607142857142857
   125	0.7590625
   150	0.8122321428571428
   175	0.8262946428571428
   200	0.8288392857142857
   225	0.8288392857142857
[snip]
   775	0.8288392857142857
   800	0.8288392857142857
   825	0.8689732142857143
   850	0.8709821428571428
   875	0.8709821428571428
[snip]
 65525	0.8709821428571428
```

This supports the above hypothesis. Most of the nodes converge very
quickly, and the rest take approximately forever to converge. Between
step 1000 and the final step 65536, the overall delta does decrease from
1.32e-05 to 7.21e-07, so real progress is being made, but on a
restricted segment of the graph.

This suggests a potential optimization. On every step, were performing
a large number of multiplications, but only 13% of these multiplications
actually have any effect. We could elect to only update those nodes
whose last delta was greater than a certain value (say, the convergence
threshold). Of course, we would have to re-evaluate all nodes every once
in a whilechanges to the distribution may cause those nodes that had
already converged to now be slightly off.
