I wrote this code with the expectation that `__compat__` info only exists on serialized data, e.g. the result of calling `toJSON()`. It's removed when the data is loaded with `fromCompat`, and attempting to attach compat info to something that already has it is an error.

This works well for classes like `Graph` and `Address` that define matching `toJSON` and `fromJSON` methods, as these methods make it easy to have canonical entry/exit points for compat info. For cases like the `repositoryJSON`, where we may directly serialize the data to disk without going through explicit `{to,from}JSON` methods, it's harder to use `compat`, as it's not clear where the entry/exit points should live. I think a reasonable resolution is to have `toJSON/fromJSON` methods for all the data that we are explicitly supporting compatibility on, and to treat any data dumped without compatibility as ephemeral. Thus, if we do make the `repositoryJSON` part of the officially supported data layer, we should define a class to hold it with to/from methods.

Thanks for the suggestion. I find your argument and proposed solution persuasive, and have updated the PR accordingly. 

This change has two additional consequences, both of which I think are good:
- As previously implemented, the `__compat__` field might show up anywhere in the JSON blob, meaning you need to parse the whole object to find the compat. Now, for any compatible object looking at the first ~100 bytes of the json is sufficient.

- As previously implemented, all compatibilized objects were compatible with compatibility-ignorant consumers, i.e. they could just ignore the `__compat__` field and proceed as usual. This is "convenient", in the type-coercion mold of "conveniently allows you to do something potentially dangerous without realizing it". Now, if you don't know that objects have been compatibilized, you probably won't know how to read them, which is a good inducement to use `fromCompat` when interpreting the object.

Something I think we should still discuss (perhaps offline) before merging: I'm not sure the `fromCompat` API is quite right. Specifically, it doesn't give any mechanism to parse version strings, just to exhaustively enumerate them. Suppose, for example, that we got in the habit of making backwards-compatible changes to serialization and recording this as proper [semver] by incrementing the minor or patch values in the version string. Then, we would need to repetitively enumerate every historical version, even when no new handler is required.

However, the API as written is very convenient for our current use case, so we could punt on improving the API and refactor it when it becomes inconvenient. (Actually, for my current intentions we don't need any handlers at all; I just want to cleanly break on old data versions. But I wanted to demonstrate that we had a composable versioning strategy, so that necessitated putting some backcompat support in the API :slightly_smiling_face: )

[semver]: https://semver.org/
Would prefer `"__compat__" in obj` here: an explicitly set `null` or `undefined` anywhere on the proto should be sufficient to fail.

>> It sounds like a consequence of what youre suggesting is that we need
>> to bump the _indexVersion whenever a node is added to the graph.
>> Consider the following scenario:
>> 
>> ```
>> const g = new Graph();
>> const ref = g.nodeReference(anAddress);
>> // now, `ref`'s internal `index` is `null`
>> assert(g.get() == null);
>> g.addNode({address: anAddress, payload: {}});
>> assert(g.get() != null);
>> ```
>> 
>> For the second assertion to succeed, the cache must have been
>> invalidated by the addNode. Or am I misunderstanding something?

When the ref has a null internal index, we attempt to correct the index every time `_ensureUpToDate` is called on that reference, which is to say, every time a graph property is requested.
Thus, calling neighbors on a phantom reference is relatively expensive, as it always goes through stringification. However, if the reference ever stops being a phantom, on the first time it is successfully used, it will adopt the correct index, and future calls will be efficient.
Thus, all phantom-reference related work is handled not when the graph is updated, but when the phantom reference is actually used.

I believe having slow lookups on phantom references is fine, since you will never encounter them "organically" - i.e. through graph traversal or calls to `nodes`. You only get them when you explicitly construct them.

Make sense?

implementing an uncached version.

1. seems totally reasonable to me.

I don't think 2. and 3. are necessary implications. When the graph gets a request for a NodeReference that does not exist in the graph, it sets its index to null. Whenever `_ensureUpToDate()` is called on that `NodeReference`, it checks its address in the graph to see if it has an index. If it does, then it can delegate to the graph to find its neighbors. If not, then it knows it has no empty and it does not have a corresponding payload. I believe this behavior is correct, and also these "phantom references" can be GC'd like any other object, are not pointed to by the graph, and generating them does not require polluting the graph's internal state.

The terms that we've been using so far are:
  - *present*: node is in the graph
  - *phantom*: node has been added to and removed from the graph (and is not in the graph)
  - *absent*: node was never in the graph
  - *isolated* (not trichotomous): node has no incident edges

be an easy way to infer `{}` as having either type `{||}` or the
unsealed object type, but didnt find much useful. It wouldnt be as
simple as inferring the intersection type `{} & {||}`; this would be
unsound. One interesting thing that I learned is that `flow type-at-pos`
in fact infers `{||}` as the type of `const emptyObject = {}`, which is
surprising given that `const emptyObject: {||} = {}` yields a type

When we do add options like you described, I think we'd need to serialize them into the graph, otherwise graph semantics are not portable / reproducible. After discussionI was misunderstanding the problem here. The above code
is sound, but wouldnt do what we want, because almost always the
reference that we get is a delegate reference, so it wont actually be
an instance of `IndexedReference`.

Furthermore, it is not unreasonable for a delegate reference to be
wrapping another delegate reference, so its not quite sufficient to
just say if its a `DelegateReference`, unpack the internal base
reference, which should probably be an `IndexedReference`wed have to
do this recursively, and even then this would only work with the
`DelegateReference` implementation that we know about, as opposed to any
other kind of implementation that users are totally free to use.

This is kind of a big problem, in my opinion: it changes the perf TODOs
from not going to bother doing this right now to its not clear that
theres actually a good way to do this, and we are incurring away what
might reasonably be a significant performance hit.

I see two reasonable options:

> Why is `address.js` this kind of pseudo-private module that shouldnt be

> ```

In offline discussions, you've noted that it's annoying importing the Graph from one file and the Address type from another. The psuedo-private module means it can be canonically imported `import {Address} from "../../core/graph"`, and come with all address methods attached, similar to how if we had used a class to back address, we wouldn't need to import every method individually.

> This is unsafe (callers may freely and typesafely modify the attributes on the object)

Didn't consider this.

> and annoying (callers can no longer import individual values). If you
export values individually, callers can either import them individually
or `import * as Address from "./address"` (which _is_ safe).

Yep, maybe that's better.

> It seems desirable that `NodeAddress` and `EdgeAddress` should be

> export opaque type NodeAddress: string = string;
> export opaque type EdgeAddress: string = string;
> ```

Sounds good, happy to do that.

> Im not dead-set against using union types in public APIs for things
like `toParts` and `concat`. However, I thoroughly disagree that this is
simplerone function that has a bounded wildcard with an upper bound
of a union type is clearly more complicated than two monomorphic
functions with simple domain and codomain. Is there an advantage here
besides implementation laziness (no offense)? 

I think we are thinking of "simplicity" in different contexts. I'm thinking about simplicity for the caller. The caller can have one set of functions for modifying addresses rather than needing to have functions specialized for node addresses and functions specialized for edge addresses.

The simplicity you're describing here - type implementation simplicity - is, imo, less important than API simplicity.

> That is, under what circumstances is there a value whose type is known to be either
`NodeAddress` or `EdgeAddress`, but were not sure which one? This
cant be a very useful type for callers, because it is incompatible with
every method on `Graph` (you cant `addNode` or `hasEdge` or anything,
and with good reason). Im feeling very when in doubt, leave it out.

I'm not sure how you imagine getting that type. Given that the user started with a `NodeAddress`, the polymorphic function will always return a `NodeAddress`, and likewise for `EdgeAddress`. 

Consider the following two snippets of code:

v1:
```js
const base = Address.nodeAddress(); // type NodeAddress
const scoped = Address.append(base, "github"); // type NodeAddress
const thisAddress = Address.append(scoped, this.id); // type NodeAddress
this.graph.addNode(thisAddress); // no flow error
```

v2:
```js
const base = NodeAddress.address(); // type NodeAddress
const scoped = NodeAddress.append(base, "github"); // type NodeAddress
const thisAddress = NodeAddress.append(scoped, this.id); // type NodeAddress
this.graph.addNode(thisAddress); // no flow error
```
In neither case do we ever instantiate something with type `NodeAddress | EdgeAddress`. The difference is the first does it with fewer API elements (since we don't need a separate `EdgeAddress` module).

Given that it doesn't produce any type-unsafety, I don't understand opposition to making the Address APIs generic. If we were implementing Python, would the same reasoning suggest that it's better to have `lenOfList` and `lenOfSet` as separate methods?

> Why allow `nodeAddress` and `edgeAddress` to be called with `undefined`?
This seems like a great way to mask bugs: if a client passes `undefined`
instead of an array, it seems at least as likely that the client has a
bug causing their intended-array to be `undefined` than that they
actually want the address given by `[]`. If a client does want this
semantics, they can just write `myArrayOrUndefined || []`.

I wanted to write the factory method so that it can be called without arguments to generate a base address. Having looked into this matter a little more, I see that `arguments.length` is a better way to achieve this.

> The following two tests would have passed in the previous API, but fail
> under the code in this pull request:

That's a bug in the implementation, thanks for catching.

> Note that `typeof NODE | typeof EDGE` is just `Symbol`; there is no
additional safety granted by using that definition.

Interesting, I guess using strings is better for that purpose.

In the case of direction, this change is a clear win. Setting direction ANY is rarely the right thing to do, so defaulting to it invites bugs.

In the case of making Node and Edge prefix mandatory, this change could seem frustrating. Sometimes it forces redundant specification; as with specifying that the `parent` of a GitHub issue is always a repo. However, in the redundant specification is redundant thanks to an invariant about how node type and edge type interrelate, and this invariant cannot be enforced locally (in code or in time). Therefore, we should not encourage users of the API to depend on unreliable invariants, given that they only afford the ability to save some keystrokes.

(I am sure we will want more sophisticated querying on addresses in the future; much more sophisticated than is possible using address prefixing. The key insight of the v3 API is that the data structure backing those queries does not need to be the graph itself. We expect it will be better to use a relational database which use the addresses as string ids. Then, we are able to use dedicated tools for managing database complexity rather than being forced to maintain our homegrown, ever more cumbersome system. And our graph can just be really good at being a graph. :slightly_smiling_face: )

> However, in the redundant specification is redundant thanks to an
> invariant about how node type and edge type interrelate, and this
> invariant cannot be enforced locally (in code or in time).

means the specification _seems_ redundant, and in fact that may
currently be the case, but new node or edge types added later could
invalidate the relevant invariant, so we are encouraging users to create
robust code.

> I am sure we will want more sophisticated querying on addresses in the

> backing those queries does not need to be the graph itself.

Looks good overall. Two comments:

1. I'd like to have the initial invariants about `inEdges` and `outEdges` also declare the type signature (contains an array of zero-or-more edges). Just so the invariants are a little more self contained. (It might be worth giving a bit more info about what an edge is in the definition.)

2. I think we can improve the performance of this invariant checking: using a counting argument, if we verify for every valid node that it is present in `_inEdges`, and every valid edge's dst appears in `_inEdges` then:
* we can count the total number of keys in `_inEdges`, to verify that there are no extra nodes appearing
* we can count the total number of entries in `_inEdges`, to verify that there are no extra edges appearing
And the same for `_outEdges`. computationally, this saves us all of the work in section 3 and 4.
As discussed offline, this should include a proof to be persuasive, and it's not yet a perf bottleneck, so we can punt on that optimization and just implement the invariants you've laid out here.

might want `ChildAddress`, `ParentAddress`, `AuthorableAddress`,
`ReferentAddress`, and `TextContentAddress`. Currently, four of those
types happen to be a union of the same four members (comment, issue,
pull request, review). If there is evidence that some of these
relationships are fundamentale.g., everything that is authorable has

```js
export type AuthorsAddress = {|
  +type: "AUTHORS",
  +author: GithubNode.UserlikeAddress,

export type MergedAsAddress = {|
  +type: "MERGED_AS",
  +pull: GithubNode.PullAddress,
|};
export type HasParentAddress = {|
  +type: "HAS_PARENT",

|};
```

My intention is to use this function when generating GitHub addresses from the GitHub graphql response. In this case, you have a JSON that you know definitely corresponds to (say) a review comment, so you call `reviewCommentUrlToId` on that json's url. This api is appropriate for that case - if anything goes wrong in getting the id out of the review comment's url, it's cause for an error. Cool; this seems like a useful function.

The implementation, however, is not correct. The problem is that the
`RegExp` constructor is not homomorphic with respect to concatenation.
That is, there is a well-defined operation of regular expression
concatenation, which is what youre trying to express, but this
operation is not equivalent to return the `RegExp` whose source is the
string concatenation of the sources of the two `RegExp`s. That is: if
we let `` denote regular expression concatenation and `++` denote
string concatenation, then it is not the case that

    RegExp (s1 ++ s2) == (RegExp s1)  (RegExp s2),

but this is the assumption that your code is making.

As a concrete example, the result of

```js
// Find an issue or pull request!
const re = githubRegex(/issues|pull/, /(\d+)/);
```

is the expression `/https:\/issues|pull\/(\d+)$/`, which is not
correct, because it matches a URL ending in `"/issues/foo/bar/baz"`.

Basically, the thing is vulnerable to regular expression injection.

We can fix this by surrounding the individual parts with non-capturing
groups, which I believe (but have not proven) to be sufficient. This
also suggests what I think is a significantly cleaner implementation:

```js
const parts = [
  /https:\/\/github.com/,
  githubNamePart,
  githubNamePart,
  ...regexParts,
];
const mainSource = parts.map((re) => `(?:${re.source})`).join("/");
return new RegExp(`^${mainSource}$`);
```

Accordingly, as you may expect, I would like to see this function
tested. :-)

What do you think about changing `EdgeInvariant` to

```js
type EdgeInvariant = {|
  +prefix: GE.RawAddress,
  +homs: $ReadOnlyArray<Hom>,
|};
type Hom = {|+src: NodeAddressT, +dst: NodeAddressT|};
```

with the semantics that any edge must match at least one of the
specified homs? Then, you could write

```js
const edgeTypeToInvariants: {[type: string]: EdgeInvariant} = {
  [GE.HAS_PARENT_TYPE]: {
    prefix: GE._Prefix.hasParent,
    homs: [
      {src: GN._Prefix.issue, dst: GN._Prefix.repo},
      {src: GN._Prefix.pull, dst: GN._Prefix.repo},
      {src: GN._Prefix.review, dst: GN._Prefix.pull},
      {src: GN._Prefix.issueComment, dst: GN._Prefix.issue},
      {src: GN._Prefix.pullComment, dst: GN._Prefix.pull},
      {src: GN._Prefix.reviewComment, dst: GN._Prefix.review},
    ],
  },
  ...rest,
};
```

for a much more expressive test. In the case where you really do want
the Cartesian product (e.g., `REFERENCES` edges), you can define

```js
declare function homProduct(
  srcs: $ReadOnlyArray<NodeAddressT>,
  dsts: $ReadOnlyArray<NodeAddressT>
): Hom[];
```

with the obvious implementation, enabling

```js
const edgeTypeToInvariants: {[type: string]: EdgeInvariant} = {
  [GE.REFERENCES_TYPE]: {
    prefix: GE._Prefix.references,
    homs: homProduct(
      [
        GN._Prefix.issue,
        GN._Prefix.pull,
        GN._Prefix.review,
        GN._Prefix.comment,
      ],
      [
        GN._Prefix.repo,
        GN._Prefix.issue,
        GN._Prefix.pull,
        GN._Prefix.review,
        GN._Prefix.comment,
        GN._Prefix.userlike,
      ]
    ),
  },
  ...rest,
};
```

for the same expressive power as the current code and just one more line
of code.

This also presents, I posit, a much more useful and reusable
abstraction.

I wonder whether we should have node creation functions. We were
considering providing a visitor for nodes, and creators are dual to
visitors (the fancy terms are anamorphisms and catamorphisms,
respectively). If you have both, then the module gains the power to
change the internal format without affecting any clients: i.e., the
structured types can be opaque. Obviously no change required in this PR.

Minor complaint (but not, I think, a nit): this is impossible in a way
that could be changed in the future such that this error is thrown at
runtime\*. I suggest either of the following alternatives:

  - Make the message clearer about what has gone wrong: this is an error
    in the invariant-checking code itself. For instance, something like
    `bad invariant for ${type}: missing accessor` would make me happier.

  - Better yet, you can encode this check statically. The problem is
    that your invariants are encoded as

    ```js
    type Invariant = {|
      +hasParent: boolean,
      +parentAccessor: ?((*) => GN.ParentAddress),
    |};
    ```

    where there is a (meta-)invariant between the value of the first
    field and the nullity of the second that is not enforced by the
    type. Instead, you could use either a union of more specific object
    types:

    ```js
    type Invariant =
      | {|+hasParent: true, +parentAccessor: (*) => GN.ParentAddress|}
      | {|+hasParent: false, +parentAccessor: null|};
    ```

    or simply functions:

    ```js
    type Invariant = ?((*) => GN.ParentAddress);
    ```

    Ive verified that each of these typechecks without the
    `null`-check, and also that the first option statically errors if
    the meta-invariant is violated (in the second option, its not
    possible to write something that violates this meta-invariant).

\* What I mean is that the impossibility is [admissible but not
derivable][1], which I think is an important didstinction.

[1]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rule_of_inference#Admissibility_and_derivability

```js
          const g = new Graph()
            .addNode(GN.toRaw(repo))
```

Just putting this out there: as I understand it, in a relational
database the typical structure for this is

```sql
CREATE TABLE repo (
  address BLOB PRIMARY KEY,
  url TEXT
);
CREATE TABLE issue (
  address BLOB PRIMARY KEY,
  title TEXT,
  body TEXT,
  url TEXT
);
CREATE TABLE has_issue (
  repo BLOB,
  issue BLOB
);
```

where you `INSERT INTO has_issue (repo, issue) VALUES (r, i)` once for
each fact that repository `r` has issue `i`.

That is, there is no array datatype, so you use an auxiliary table to
express the relationship `has_issue : repo  issue`.

No change necessary in this PR, but maybe keep this in the back of your
mind so that you dont start doing crazy things that dont fit into this
model.

The second and third commits are fine with me, but I am skeptical of the
change to denormalize everything. This implies that the `RelationalView`
is no longer a view of a relational database but rather a view of a
[document-oriented database][dodb] (like MongoDB).

[dodb]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Document-oriented_database

Here is one practical problem presented by this example: in our example
repo, there are only two users, but the URL for `decentralion` appears
12 times and the URL for `wchargin` appears 6 times. It is easy to see
that this will lead to a lot of data duplication. This is worse than
just wasted space: we now have to ensure that these are all kept in
sync (namely, that `login` should be a super key).

This approach is the approach taken by the GitHub v3 API, whichyoull
recallyields [results like this][ghv3], wherein requesting the comments
on an issue requires serving 40 copies of URLs to various aspects of
@decentralions login page.

[ghv3]: https://api.github.com/repos/sourcecred/sourcecred/issues/350/comments

This approach also has the consequence that objects explode in size: a
reference to a repository now includes the full contents of all pull
request review comments under the repository.

As I understand it, youre denormalizing to avoid null checks in the
client code. In a relational model, this isnt a problem. If you want
all the pull request review comments on all the reviews of a given pull
request, you can

```sql
SELECT *
FROM pulls JOIN reviews JOIN review_comments
ON pulls.id = reviews.pull AND review_comments.review = reviews.id
WHERE pulls.id = ?
```

which is all type-checked and everything by the server.
([Example fiddle.][fiddle])

Id strongly request reconsidering this, and Im happy to chat about it.

[fiddle]: http://sqlfiddle.com/#!5/a05bf/2

```sql
CREATE TABLE pulls (

);

INSERT INTO reviews VALUES ('r1', 'p2');
```

Let me take a step back to pose a high-level question.

I agree that standardizing on a UI toolkit is a good idea and something
that we should do. We dont want to roll our own custom UI widgets,
because then we have to make sure that theyre accessible,
high-performance, consistently designed, and so on.

Whichever toolkit we select will quickly permeate our frontend, and the
decision may be hard to change later. Thus, we should choose carefully.

Im concerned by the bundle size and build time penalties incurred by
Semantic UI:

| build ref        | `main.js` size |    build time |
|:-----------------|---------------:|--------------:|
| origin/master    |      439646 B |      19.112 s |
| origin/ui-update |    1408500 B |      39.077 s |

Semantic UI is adding 968.8 KB to the build, and more than doubling the
build time. For comparison, [all of Material-UI is 95.4 KB][mui] (and
Material-UI supports directly importing individual components), and
[React itself (16.2.0 + DOM) is 97.5 KB][react].

(I built against origin/ui-update, not origin/update-navbar, because
this branch doesnt actually use `semantic-ui-react`.)

[mui]: https://github.com/mui-org/material-ui/blob/0efc81dad607437fa448d6b19a2c985266790848/.size-limit.js#L27-L30
[react]: https://gist.github.com/Restuta/cda69e50a853aa64912d

So, Id like to consider other options. Material-UI seems well supported
and maintained. React-Bootstrap is fine (Ive used it in the past), if a
Bootstrap-like look is what youre going for, and Elemental UI looks
pretty similar. What else should we be considering?

I also want to explicitly mention that I value the time and effort that
youve put into this set of changes. In the long run, though, I think
that it would be a mistake to base an architectural decision like this
one around the fact that we already have a bit of code written. Plus,
even if we end up scratching the technical implementation of this
changeset entirely, your work wont have been wastedin addition to the
actual code, youve spent time exploring different designs, and become
acquainted with the codebase, tools, and environment. All of that will
carry over.

@decentralion: anything I forgot to mention?

---

Another option that I want to float (though I suspect that it may be an
unpopular suggestion) is to use the unique UI toolkit that adds zero
build time and zero bundle size. You can go a long way by just styling
the standard DOM elements. Ive used that approach in the past for [this
application][vt], which doesnt look half bad, if you ask me. Choosing
to use the standard library is different from rolling your own
components: you get accessibility, performance, etc. for free.

Im not saying that we should _definitely_ do this, but I do think that
we should consider alternatives in terms of their marginal benefits over
using the standard library.

[vt]: https://wchargin.github.io/varese/#/tree

> would you mind taking a look into why this is failing?

Changing the offending assertion to

```js
    expect(el.instance().props.localStore).toBe(localStore);
```

causes the test to pass. This is because `el.props()` returns the props
for the element rendered by the component, not the component itself. So,
youre seeing the props for the outermost `div`. (Confirm with
`expect(el.props()).toBe(Symbol())` and inspecting the error.

This is a strange decision, but it is documented:

<https://github.com/airbnb/enzyme/blob/290253d346200c2997a98fa053f76a1c0895e899/docs/api/ShallowWrapper/props.md>

Nit incoming, but one that I care about somewhat. Youve a couple times
now written code of the form

```js
        const totalScore = aggregation.connections.reduce(
          (val, connection) => val + connection.connectionScore,
          0
        );
```

, which can be rewritten as

```js
        const scores = aggregation.connections.map((x) => x.connectionScore);
        const totalScore = scores.reduce((a, b) => a + b);
```

. I posit that the latter is better, both for ivory-tower purity
reasons\* and for practical reasons. The practical reason is simply the
following: while it is not _difficult_ to rederive at each occasion
whether the accumulator or the next item comes as the first argument to
the callback, it requires active thought each time that you read the
code (for me, at least, and Im not alone). When your accumulator type
is different from your element type, the order matters. When you map
first so that everything is homogeneous, it doesnt.\*\*

I think that this is consonant with the principle that code is read much
more often than its written; the obviously correct version is better
than the slightly-nonobviously correct version.

Another practical reason is that its impossible to get wrong if you map
first and then reduce. If you got the arguments wrong here, youd get
`0` for an empty array or `"[object Object]undefined"` for a nonempty
array. Sure, tests will catch it, but why bother tracking down that bug?

\* The ivory-tower reason is roughly that when you perform a true
_reduction_, as opposed to a fold, you have much more freedom in terms
of execution strategy. For instance, it is trivial to parallelize a
reduction, but it is impossible to parallelize a fold. This really does
matter in principle (you sacrifice O(log *n*) for O(*n*)), but in
practice this code is not parallel, and if we want to make it parallel
then we can trivially make the transformation.

\*\* This is true even if the operator is non-commutativeask me for
details if you care.

SoI care about this enough to write my own code in my preferred style,
and I want to let you know where Im coming from. But if you have any
remotely good reasons for favoring the former style in any particular
case then Im happy to let it slide.

\</nit> :-)
